content:
Hi,
Thank you for visiting my page.
I am a graduate student at Institute of Life Sciences, India working in the area of Computational Biology. My PhD research topic is epigenetic regulation of immune response in dendritic cells. Corepressors protein plays an important role in dynamic epigenetic modifications such as acetylation and deacetylation of chromatin that regulates gene expression. I am investigating role of these corepressors protein in regulating multiple immmune response upon dendritic cells activation.
I mainly use high througputput sequencing data such as RNASeq and ChIPseq to understand epigenetic regulation.
I feel really great working in this area of research that provides an immense opportunity to always learn something new from other disciplines.
I am also part of eLife Ambassadors Programmne to promote open science and reproducibility.
summary:

title: Gyan Prakash Mishra

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
This guide will help you to create your own GitHub Page from scratch using R package blogdown.
 Note : This tutorial assumes that you some background knowlege of R.
 So the first step is to install blogdown package.
# install install.packages("blogdown") #load the library library(blogdown) Before getting started check whether hugo is installed in your system or not. If not, install using below command.
sudo apt-get install hugo After successful installation of package blogdown and hugo you are ready to build your webpage. you can choose your theme of interest from here.
# set your working directory where you want to build your site. setwd("github_page") # Here I have used hugo-academic theme version 4.2.5 blogdown::new_site(dir=".",format = "toml",theme = "gcushen/hugo-academic@v4.2.5") The folder “github_page” will be populated with several files required for bulding webpage as you can see below.
> list.files() [1] "config" "config.toml" "content" "index.Rmd" "public" "resources" "static" "themes" To render the content of the “github_page” folder as webpage use following codes.
# buld webpage to another folder (e.g render) blogdown::build_dir("render") options(blogdown.publishDir="render") blogdown::build_site() Next, serve the hugo template that is built from above lines of code.
Here you go.
blogdown::serve_site() The folder “render” will pe populated with the content of the webpage. Modify the markdown files and .toml inside the “render” folder as per your requirement and your webpage will be ready to publish.
After you have modified the conent and ready to go online, create a repository at github with extension “.github.io” (for e.g your_webpage_name.github.io).
Now the final step is to push the content of the “render” folder to github repository that we created above.
# open terminal cd render # make sure that git is already installed in your system. git init git add . git commit -m "First commit" git remote add origin https://github.com/your_webpage_name/your_webpage_name.github.io git push origin master Congrats you have succesfully created your GitHub webpage !
I would like to thank Arup Ghosh for his help in creating this webpage and tutorial.
summary:
This guide will help you to create your own GitHub Page from scratch using R package blogdown.
 Note : This tutorial assumes that you some background knowlege of R.
 So the first step is to install blogdown package.
# install install.packages("blogdown") #load the library library(blogdown) Before getting started check whether hugo is installed in your system or not. If not, install using below command.
sudo apt-get install hugo After successful installation of package blogdown and hugo you are ready to build your webpage.
title: Simple steps to create your own GitHub webpage

content:
Welcome to Slides Academic
Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides  Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E  Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")  Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = \;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears  Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view   Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links   night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links  Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}  Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }  Questions? Ask
Documentation
summary:

Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides  Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E  Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")  Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
